revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=November 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2015}} {{Burmese name| Ashin}} {{Infobox religious biography |background = #FFD068 | color = black |name =U Wirathu
{{my|ဝီရသူ}} |image= |image_size = 200px |caption = U Wirathu |birth name = [[Burmese name#Honorifics|Maung]] |alias = Win Khaing Oo |dharma name = Ashin Vicittasārābhivamsa |birth_date = {{b-da|10 July 1968}} |birth_place = [[Kyaukse]], [[Mandalay Division]], [[Burmese Way to Socialism|Burma]] (now [[Myanmar]]) |temple = [[Masoyein Monastery]], [[Mandalay]] |death_date = |death_place = |nationality = Burmese |religion = [[Buddhism]] |school = [[Theravada]] |lineage = |title = |location = |education = |occupation = [[Bhikkhu|Buddhist monk]] |teacher = |predecessor = |successor = |students = |website = }} '''Wirathu''' ({{lang-my|ဝီရသူ}}; born 10 July 1968 in [[Kyaukse]], [[Mandalay Division]], [[Burmese Way to Socialism|Burma]]) is a [[Myanmar|Burmese]] [[Buddhist]] [[monk]], and the communal leader of the anti-Muslim movement in Myanmar.{{cite news|title=Two documentaries probe Myanmar’s religious strife|url=https://www.economist.com/blogs/prospero/2017/07/will-fight|accessdate=28 February 2018|work=The Economist|language=en}} He has been accused of conspiring to [[Persecution of Muslims in Myanmar|persecute Muslims in Myanmar]] through his speeches, although he claims to be a peaceful preacher and not to have advocated violence—which is disputed by others. [[Facebook]] also banned his page on the charge of spreading religious hatred towards other communities, after repeated warnings to not post religiously inflammatory content.https://amp.scroll.in/article/870245/facebook-removes-myanmar-monks-page-for-inflammatory-posts-about-muslims == Background == Wirathu was born in 1968 near [[Mandalay]]. He left school at the age 14 to become a monk. In 2001, he became involved in the [[969 Movement]].{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-22356306|title=Why are Buddhist monks attacking Muslims?|newspaper=BBC|date=1 May 2013|author=Alan Strathern}} Two years later, in 2003, he was sentenced to 25 years in prison for his sermons,{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/apr/18/buddhist-monk-spreads-hatred-burma|title=Buddhist monk uses racism and rumours to spread hatred in Burma|date=28 April 2013|author=Kate Hodal|newspaper=Guardian}} but was released in 2012 along with many other political prisoners.{{cite web|author=The Irrawaddy |url=http://www.irrawaddy.com/interview/nationalist-monk-u-wirathu-denies-role-in-anti-muslim-unrest.html |title=Nationalist Monk U Wirathu Denies Role in Anti-Muslim Unrest |publisher=Irrawaddy.com |date= |accessdate=2018-02-28}} Since the government reforms of 2011, he has been especially active on [[YouTube]] and other forms of social media.{{cite news|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/articles/450375/20130326/saydaw-wirathu-myanmar-969-burma.htm|title=Fanatical Buddhist Monk Saydaw Wirathu Calling for Boycott of Myanmar Muslims|newspaper=International Business Times|author=Gianluca Mezzofiore|date=26 March 2013}} [[Facebook]] banned his page on the charge of spreading religious hatred towards other communities, after repeated warnings to not post religiously inflammatory content. He has been warned by other social networking sites. == Political engagement == Wirathu led a rally of monks in Mandalay in September 2012 to promote President [[Thein Sein]]'s controversial plan to send Burmese [[Rohingya]] Muslims to a third country.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/apr/18/buddhist-monk-spreads-hatred-burma|title=Buddhist monk uses racism and rumours to spread hatred in Burma - The Guardian|date=18 April 2013|newspaper=The Guardian|author=Kate Hodal}} One month later, more violence broke out in Rakhine state. Wirathu claims the violence in Rakhine was the spark for the most recent violence in Myanmar's central city of [[Meiktila]], where a dispute in a gold shop quickly spiraled into a looting-and-arson spree. More than 14 people were killed, after monasteries, shops and houses were burned down across the city.{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/03/22/world/asia/myanmar-clashes/index.html|title= Muslims, clash with Rakhines in Myanmar|date=22 March 2013|author=Phyo Wai Lin, Jethro Mullen and Kocha Olarn|newspaper=CNN}}{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/1305/24/ampr.01.html|date=24 May 2013|title={{sic|Inte|view|hide=y}} with Myanmar's President|newspaper=CNN}} At least two people, including a Burmese Buddhist monk, Shin Thawbita, and a Muslim man were reportedly assaulted and tortured by mobs in Meikhtilar on 5 March.{{cite news|url=http://e.koreanpress.net/detail.php?number=1370&thread=22r02r01|title=The Rohingya Saga|date=21 June 2013|newspaper=Korean Press News}} Wirathu is mentioned on the cover story of [[Time (magazine)|''Time'' magazine]] as "The Face of Buddhist Terror" on 20 June 2013.{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,2146000,00.html#ixzz2Wo5x4M7Q|title=The Face of Buddhist Terror|date=1 July 2013|newspaper=Time Magazine|author=Hannah Beech}} "You can be full of kindness and love, but you cannot sleep next to a mad dog," Wirathu said, referring to Muslims. "If we are weak," he said, "our land will become Muslim." {{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/06/21/world/asia/extremism-rises-among-myanmar-buddhists-wary-of-muslim-minority.html|date=20 June 2013|title=Extremism Rises Among Myanmar Buddhists|newspaper=New York Times|author=Thomas Fuller}} Referring to Muslim violence and domination in neighbouring nations and the example of the [[spread of Islam in Indonesia]],{{cite news|title=Militant Buddhist monks are stoking sectarian tensions in Myanmar|url=https://www.economist.com/news/asia/21726120-they-claim-muslim-minority-poses-mortal-threat-their-religion-militant-buddhist-monks-are|accessdate=11 August 2017|work=[[The Economist]]|date=10 August 2017}} Wirathu worries about a similar fate for Myanmar.{{cite news|url=http://frontpagemag.com/2013/raymond-ibrahim/buddhist-extremism/|title=Buddhist Extremism?|author=Raymond Ibrahim|newspaper=Front Page Magazine|date=2 August 2013}} Wirathu claims that his Muslim opponents labelled him the "Burmese Bin Laden" after the ''Time'' article incorrectly reported he described himself in this manner.{{cite news|url=http://www.rfa.org/english/news/myanmar/monk-06212013182954.html|date=21 June 2013|newspaper=Radio Free Asia|title=Myanmar Monk Rejects Terrorist Label Following Communal Clashes|author=Khin Khin Ei}} He said he "abhorred violence" and "opposes terrorism". Wirathu has also expressed admiration for, and a desire to follow the example of, the [[English Defence League]] by "protecting the public."{{cite news|url=http://www.nypost.com/p/news/international/radical_killed_islamic_buddhist_uyZ3kWgomlxZz3g05KqbqJ|title=Radical Buddhist monk accused of inciting riots that have killed hundreds of Muslims|date=21 June 2013|newspaper=New York Post}} [[Thein Sein]] accused ''Time'' of slandering the Buddhist religion and harming the national reconciliation process by accusing the outspoken cleric of stoking anti-Muslim violence in Myanmar. Describing him as a "son of Buddha", the president defended Wirathu as a "noble person" committed to peace. "The article in Time Magazine can cause misunderstanding about the [[Buddhist]] religion, which has existed for millennia and is followed by the majority of [[Myanmar|Burmese]] citizens," Thein Sein said.{{cite news|url=http://www.dvb.no/news/politics-news/burma-president-backs-anti-muslim-%E2%80%98hate-preacher%E2%80%99-wirathu/28955|title=Burma president backs anti-Muslim 'hate preacher' Wirathu|date=26 June 2013|newspaper=Democratic Voice of Burma|author=Hanna Hindstrom}} In an interview with DVB, Wirathu accused ''Time'' of committing a "serious human rights violation" by refusing to present his views in a verbatim question and answer format. "Before I had heard [rumours] of the Arab world dominating the global media," he said, "but this time, I've seen it for myself." Wirathu openly blamed Muslims for instigating the recent violence. Wirathu claimed that Myanmar's Muslims are being financed by Middle Eastern forces, saying, "The local Muslims are crude and savage because the extremists are pulling the strings, providing them with financial, military and technical power".{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/apr/18/buddhist-monk-spreads-hatred-burma|title=Buddhist monk uses racism and rumours to spread hatred in Burma|first=Kate|last=Hodal|date=18 April 2013|publisher=|via=www.theguardian.com}} On 21 July 2013, he was the apparent target of a bomb explosion, but he remained unscathed. Five people were slightly injured in the blast, including a novice monk. Wirathu claimed that the bombing was an attempt by Muslim extremists to silence his voice.{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887324783204578620901385432658|title=Blast Near Monk Injures 5 in Myanmar|date=22 Jul 2013|newspaper=Wall Street Journal|author=Shibani Mahtani and Myo Myo}}{{cite news|url=http://asiancorrespondent.com/110917/burma-police-explosion-in-mandalay-wounds-5/|title=Burma police: Explosion near Wirathu sermon in Mandalay wounds 5|date=22 Jul 2013|newspaper=AP News}}{{cite news|url=http://www.rfa.org/english/news/myanmar/bomb-07222013184528.html|title=Myanmar's Nationalist Monk Claims Bombers Sought to 'Silence Him'|date=22 Jul 2013|newspaper=Radio Free Asia|author=Khin Maung Soe and Yadanar Oo}} He has called for restrictions on marriages between Buddhists and Muslims,{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887323829104578619462267929512|title=Myanmar Plan to Curb Interfaith Marriage Gains Support|date=22 July 2013|newspaper=Wall Street Journal|author=Shibani Mahtani}} and for boycotts of Muslim-owned businesses. However, not everyone from within his own faith agrees with his teachings. [[Abbot (Buddhism)|Abbot]] Arriya Wuttha Bewuntha of [[Mandalay|Mandalay's]] Myawaddy Sayadaw monastery denounced him, saying, "He sides a little towards hate [and this was] not the way [[Buddha]] taught. What the Buddha taught is that hatred is not good, because Buddha sees everyone as an equal being. The Buddha doesn't see people through religion." Critics also explain what they see as his extremism as little more than due to ignorance, although his views do have influence in Myanmar where many businesses are "run successfully by Muslims". Burmese pro-democracy activist [[Maung Zarni]] also denounced Wirathu's 969 Movement for spreading [[hate speech]] and argued that EU countries should take the matter seriously as Myanmar is a "major EU-aid recipient country". In September 2014, Wirathu attended a "Great Sangha Conference" in [[Colombo]] organised by [[Bodu Bala Sena]]. Wirathu said that his [[969 Movement]] would work with the [[Bodu Bala Sena]].{{cite news|title=Ashin Wirathu Thera of Myanmar to work with BBS |url=http://www.dailymirror.lk/news/53056-ashin-wirathu-thera-of-myanmar-to-work-with-bbs.html|work=[[Daily Mirror (Sri Lanka)]]|date=28 September 2014}} In January 2015 Wirathu publicly called United Nations envoy [[Yanghee Lee]] a "bitch" and a "whore"{{Cite news |author=Tim Hume |title=Top U.N. official slams Myanmar monk over 'whore' comments |publisher=CNN |date=22 January 2015 |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2015/01/22/world/myanmar-united-nations-wirathu/}}{{Cite news |title=UN condemns Myanmar monk Wirathu's 'sexist' comments |work=BBC Asia |date=22 January 2016 |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-30928744}} and invited her to "offer your arse to the ''kalars''" (a derogatory term for Muslims).{{Cite news |author=Mangala Dilip |title=Anti-Muslim Myanmar Buddhist Monk Wirathu Calls UN Envoy 'Bitch and Whore' |newspaper=International Business Times |date=20 January 2015 |url=http://www.ibtimes.co.in/myanmar-buddhist-monk-wirathu-abuses-un-envoy-video-620927}}{{Cite news |author=Maddie Smith |title=Myanmar’s Extremist Monk Doesn’t Regret Calling UN Envoy a ‘Whore’ |newspaper=Vice News |date=22 January 2016 |url=https://news.vice.com/article/myanmars-extremist-monk-doesnt-regret-calling-un-envoy-a-whore}} Wirathu led a prayer and protest at the [[Mahamuni Buddha Temple]] in [[Mandalay]] on February 23, 2017, to condemn the Thai government's raid on the [[Wat Phra Dhammakaya]] in [[Bangkok]].Zarni Mann [https://www.irrawaddy.com/news/burma/u-wirathu-leads-protest-solidarity-dhammakaya-temple.html "U Wirathu Leads Protest in Solidarity with Dhammakaya Temple"], ''[[The Irrawaddy]]'', Myanmar, 24 February 2017 [[Ayeyarwady Region]]'s government banned Wirathu from preaching in the region on 10 March 2017.EMG Reporter [http://elevenmyanmar.com/local/8252 "Buddhist monk banned from preaching in Ayeyarwady"], ''[[Weekly Eleven]]'', 11 March 2017 ==See also== * [[2013 Myanmar anti-Muslim riots]] * [[969 Movement]] * [[Bodu Bala Sena]] * [[Patriotic Association of Myanmar]] * [[South Thailand insurgency]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Wikiquote}} * [http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,2146000,00.html#ixzz2WqicKHQA The Face of Buddhist Terror] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qvEBaAiy5b4 A Burmese Journey Q&A With Ashin Wirathu (English subtitles)] {{DEFAULTSORT:Wirathu}} [[Category:1968 births]] [[Category:Critics of Islam]] [[Category:Burmese prisoners and detainees]] [[Category:Buddhist religious leaders]] [[Category:Burmese Buddhist monks]] [[Category:Theravada Buddhist monks]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Opposition to Islam in Myanmar]] [[Category:People from Mandalay Region]] [[Category:Buddhism-related controversies]]

{{EngvarB|date=October 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} The '''Association of Catholic Priests''' (ACP) is a voluntary association of [[Roman Catholic]] [[Priesthood (Catholic Church)|clergy]] in Ireland. The association was established in September 2010 with the claimed objective of having "a forum, and a voice to reflect, discuss and comment on issues affecting the [[Roman Catholicism in Ireland|Irish Church]] and society today".[http://www.associationofcatholicpriests.ie/ Association of Catholic Priests website] One of its founders was Fr [[Tony Flannery]] who, in April 2012, was disciplined by the [[Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith]] for questioning whether Jesus Christ had instituted the priesthood. His brother [[Frank Flannery]] is a former General Secretary of the [[Fine Gael]] party. ==Theology== The ACP says that it accepts the [[Nicene Creed|Creed]] and that it does not seek to overturn the [[dogma|defined teaching]] of the Catholic Church but these are questionable claims given its attempts to undermine settled Church teaching on issues like adultery and contraception [http://www.catholicworldreport.com/Item/1284/belonging_without_believing.aspx] ==Vocations== In June 2014, the issue of vocations was discussed at the Irish Catholic Bishops Conference in Maynooth. The ACP called for the Church to have a plan for vocations. Father Sean McDonagh says that the Church is "facing an implosion in terms of vocations to the priesthood.".[http://www.thejournal.ie/vocations-catholic-church-ireland-1507303-Jun2014/ The Journal] - retrieved 11 June 2014 In this regard, the ACP advocates the appointment of female [[deacon]]s. According to Fr.McDonagh:
"It’s fairly clear historically that women have served in the Church, despite every effort to silence their voices since the 4th century."
The ACP also called for men who left the priesthood to marry to be called back to ministry in some form. McDonagh claimed that if the ACP’s recommendations were not acted on, parish churches could be forced to close down. ==Communion== The report of the [[Apostolic visitation to Ireland]] expressed some concerns about the ''communio'' ([[Communion (Christian)|communion or unity]]) of the Church. The ACP claims "We cherish and we value and we wish to further the unity of all our people, with our fellow clergy, with [[Religious (Catholicism)|Religious]], with our bishops and with the [[Primacy of Simon Peter|Successor of Peter]]." ==Censure== Members of the association have been [[censure]]d by the [[Roman Curia]]. The Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith (CDF) placed restrictions on the association's founder, Fr Tony Flannery who is a member of the [[Congregation of the Most Holy Redeemer|Redemptorist Congregation]].{{cite web |url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2012/0406/lay-organisations-criticise-vatican-investigation.html |title=Lay organisations criticise Vatican investigation|date=10 April 2012|publisher=[[RTÉ.ie]]|accessdate=12 April 2012}} He was advised by Rome to go to a monastery where he might "pray and reflect" on his heterodox views and his role with the association. His monthly column in the congregation's monthly magazine, "Reality", has been discontinued. Restrictions have also been imposed on the magazine itself and its editor, Fr Gerard Moloney.[http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2012/0406/1224314438131.html Irish Times], ''Vatican moves to quell internal dissenting voices", 6 April 2012. Retrieved 20 May 2012 Supporters of the censure cite that the Vatican has "a sacred obligation to investigate any religious whose teaching is [[Criticism of the Catholic Church|contrary to that of the church]]: to defend those sacred teachings: and to protect the faithful from all taint of error and corruption."[http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/letters/2012/0411/1224314607424.html Irish Times], ''Vatican and dissenting voices'', letter by John Ferry, Marymount, Sligo. Other supporters advocate that those censured by the CDF are free to set up a rival church:
"Those with strong private theories and opinions have plenty of churches to choose from and, if they find none to their liking, they can always set up another.[http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/letters/2012/0412/1224314639685.html Irish Times], ''Vatican and dissenting voices'', 12 April 2012. A letter by Mary Stewart, Ardeskin, Donegal. Retrieved 20 May 2012.
Since that time, it has emerged that three other priests have also been silenced: [[Society of Mary (Marists)|Marist]] priest Fr Seán Fagan, [[Order of Friars Minor Capuchin|Capuchin]] priest Fr Owen O'Sullivan and [[Passionists|Passionist]] priest Fr [[Brian D'Arcy]]. At a conference organised by the ACP in [[Dublin]]'s Regency Hotel, Fr Brendan Hoban told the gathering "that clamping down on "wayward" opinions was not the way to deal with issues".[http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/local-national/republic-of-ireland/silencing-us-wont-solve-catholic-churchs-problems-say-priests-16155442.html#ixzz1xnrGiYU8 "Silencing us won't solve Catholic Church's problems, say priests"], ''Belfast Telegraph'', 8 May 2012. Retrieved 14 June 2012. ==Achievements== Its intervention in the case of [[Kevin Reynolds (priest)|Fr Kevin Reynolds]], who was libelled in RTÉ's "Prime Time Investigates" programme – [[Mission to Prey]] – in May 2011 was instrumental is securing an apology from the broadcaster. In April 2012 it published a survey that it commissioned which revealed that nine out of 10 of the 1,000 interviewed practising Catholics (35 per cent attend Mass once a week, 51 per cent once or more each month and 20 per cent a few times a year) said priests should be allowed to marry, with 77 per cent believing women should be ordained and three-quarters of respondents not seeing Catholic Church teachings on sexuality as relevant to them or to their family.[http://www.scotsman.com/the-scotsman/international/irish-catholics-call-for-married-priests-and-ordination-of-women-1-2231364 "Irish Catholics Call for Married Priests and Ordination of Women"], ''The Scotsman'' 13 April 2012, accessed 22 May 2012[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-17699603 "Survey Finds Irish Catholics 'want married priests'"], BBC News Northern Ireland 13 April 2012, accessed 22 May 2012 On 30 May 2012, a steering group under the umbrella of the ACP met in [[All Hallows College]], Dublin. The meeting, was attended by about 200 people and resulted in the establishment of a new lay organisation for Irish Catholics with an interim title of the "Association of Catholics in Ireland". The new association committed itself to "the renewal of the Catholic faith in the changed and changing circumstances of the 21st century and to the reform of the institutional church which, at this time, is experiencing conflict, crisis and lack of credibility".[http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2012/0728/1224320947480.html Irish Times], "Lay organisation for Catholics to promote 'spirit of Vatican II'”, 28 July 2012. Retrieved 29 July 2012 In November 2012, at a meeting attended by over 300 people, the objectives of the [[Association of Catholics in Ireland]] were formally approved. ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==See also== * [[A Call To Action]] ==External links== *[http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/09056a.htm Catholic Encyclopedia: Canon Law] *[http://www.vatican.va/holy_father/john_paul_ii/apost_constitutions/documents/hf_jp-ii_apc_25011983_sacrae-disciplinae-leges_en.html Document establishing the 1983 Code of Canon Law] * [http://www.seanoconaill.com/ Home page of Sean O'Conaill] * [http://www.uscatholicpriests.org/ Association of US Catholic Priests] [[Category:Religion in the Republic of Ireland]] [[Category:Catholic Church in Ireland]] [[Category:Volunteer cooperatives]] [[Category:Catholic organizations established in the 21st century]]

page.title: Así en el cielo como en la tierra

revision.text:
{{Infobox film | name = Así en el cielo como en la tierra | image = | alt = | caption = | director = [[José Luis Cuerda]] | producer = | writer = [[José Luis Cuerda]] | starring = [[Fernando Fernán Gómez]]
[[Francisco Rabal]]
[[Jesús Bonilla]]
[[Mary Carmen Ramírez]]
[[Luis Ciges]]
[[Gabino Diego]]
[[Chus Lampreabe]]
[[Mónica Molina]] | music = | cinematography = | editing = | distributor = | released = {{Film date|1995}} | runtime = 95 minutes | country = [[Spain]] | language = [[Spanish language|Spanish]] | budget = | gross = }} '''''Así en el cielo como en la tierra''''' (On earth as it is in heaven) is a 1995 [[Spain|Spanish]] [[comedy film]] directed by [[José Luis Cuerda]]. ==Plot== Matacanes arrives at [[Heaven]] but it is not exactly as he imagined it, as it resembles a typical Spanish village with [[God]] as the mayor and [[Saint Peter]] as a [[Civil Guard (Spain)|civil guard]] (although Saint Peter explains that this is Spanish Heaven and other countries' heavens are different) Some people, however, are nervous because God, unhappy with things on Earth, is planning to have another child. [[Jesus]] becomes jealous and tries to convince his father to accelerate the [[Apocalypse]] instead. ==Critical reception== Fernando Morales in [[El País]] wrote that the movie just barely get a pass, despite the good casting.[https://elpais.com/diario/1997/07/29/radiotv/870127206_850215.html Así en el cielo corno en la tierra] in elpais.com. [[Carlos Aguilar (writer)|Carlos Aguilar]] in his ''Guía del cine español'' praises the premise and the actor's performances but concludes that the film "lacks shape and rhythm".{{cite book |last= Aguilar |first= Carlos |title= Guía del cine español |url= |accessdate= |language= |others= |year= 2007 |editor= |publisher= Cátedra |isbn=978-84-376-2419-8 |page= 126 }} ==External links== * {{IMDB title|id=0112403|title=Así en el cielo como en la tierra}} ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Spanish films]] [[Category:1995 films]] [[Category:Spanish-language films]] [[Category:Films about the afterlife]] [[Category:Religious comedy films]] [[Category:1990s comedy films]] {{1990s-Spain-film-stub}} {{christian-film-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2016}} {{Use British English|date=May 2016}} {{Infobox television | show_name = ''Bones of the Buddha'' | image = | caption = | show_name_2 = ''Secrets of the Dead: Bones of the Buddha | genre = [[History documentary]] | writer = [[Steven Clarke]] | director = Steven Clarke | presenter = Charles Allen | narrated = [[Charles Dance]] (UK)
[[Jay O. Sanders]] (US) | composer = | country = [[United Kingdom]] | language = English | num_episodes = 1 | executive_producer = | producer = | location = | runtime = | company = | channel = | picture_format = | audio_format = | first_aired = {{start date|2013|7|23|df=yes}} | last_aired = | preceded_by = | followed_by = | related = | website = }} '''''Bones of the Buddha''''' is a 2013 television documentary produced by [[Icon Films]] and commissioned by [[WNET|WNET/THIRTEEN]] and [[Arte|ARTE France]] for the [[National Geographic Channel]]s. It concerns a controversial [[Reliquary#In Buddhism|Buddhist reliquary]] from the [[Piprahwa|Piprahwa Stupa]] in [[Uttar Pradesh]], [[India]]. It was released in May, 2013, and was broadcast in July 2013 in the US on [[PBS]] as part of the ''[[Secrets of the Dead]]'' series. ==Content== Writer and host [[Charles Allen (writer)|Charles Allen]] investigates the [[Piprahwa]] Stupa, a large [[stupa|Buddhist Stupa]] which is argued to be one of the eight resting places of the [[Gautama Buddha|Buddha's]] ashes.''The Buddha and Dr Führer'', (2008) Charles Allen, Haus Publishing, London In 1898, estate manager and amateur archaeologist W.C. Peppé excavated the stupa, finding a large brick dome with a sarcophagus, or coffer, at the center. Inside were four vessels (three stoneware, one glass) along with about 1600 small jewels and gold pieces — the Piprahwa treasure — all of undetermined age. One of the stoneware vessels — the "Piprahwa reliquary" — contained jewels mixed with human ashes and bone. Peppé made the mistake of consulting Dr [[Alois Anton Führer]] — a German archaeologist who soon became notorious for forging other Buddhist relics — and the Piprahwa find, along with Peppé's own reputation, were soon irretrievably tainted with scandal and the "Buddha's bones" discredited in the professional archeological world. In presenting the background to the story, Allen visits the Buddhist sites of [[Kushinagar]] and [[Sanchi]], as well as the old Peppé family manor house, now in a state of extreme neglect. Allen interviews [[Harry Falk]] (professor of [[Indology]] at the [[Free University of Berlin|Freie Universität]] in [[Berlin]] and said to be the "world's foremost expert" in ancient Indian languages and history), who states that Führer could not have forged the Piprahwa reliquary inscription. This is, Falk says, because he lacked sufficient knowledge of the language ([[Prakrit]]) in which its inscription was written, and, more importantly, he could have never known the [[Sanskrit]] word ''nidhane'' ("container"), which is written on the reliquary, a ''[[hapax legomenon]]'' (unique example) in the entire corpus of [[Brahmi]] script. That said, however, it should be noted that Führer had taught Sanskrit for three years at [[St. Xavier's College, Bombay]],Arx, Urs von (2005). In Marco Jorio, [http://www.hls-dhs-dss.ch/textes/d/D28760.php Historisches Lexikon der Schweiz] vol. 4, Basel: Schwabe and was one of the editors of [[Epigraphia Indica]];Führer, Alois Anton; Hultzsch, E; Burgess, James (1892-1894). Epigraphia Indica: a collection of inscriptions supplementary to the Corpus inscriptionum Indicarum, Calcutta: Government printing that he had translated Sanskrit texts, and that ''nidhane'' occurs commonly enough in such Sanskrit textual sources. Falk concludes that the reliquary found at Piprahwa in 1898 did contain a portion of the ashes of the Buddha,{{refn | group = note |Theodor Bloch commented on the bone relics exvacated by Peppe: "one may still be permitted to maintain some doubts in regard to the theory that the latter monument contained the relic share of Buddha received by the Sakyas. The bones at that place, which have been presented to the King of Siam, and which I saw in Calcutta, according to my opinion were not human bones at all."Bloch, Theodor, ‘Notes on the Exploration of Vaisali’, Annual Report, Bengal Circle, Archaeological Survey of India, year ended April 1904, p. 15 {{OCLC|64218646}}}} and that the inscription is authentic.{{refn | group = note |In his review of Harry Falks new book "Aśokan Sites and Artefacts", Michael Willis comments: "As the question of fakes is raised by Falk himself, it is noteworthy that the author has side-stepped the Piprahwa reliquary in the India Museum, Calcutta, in all likelihood a forgery made by A. A. Führer whose activities are explored elsewhere in this JRAS special issue. The decision to side-step this problem was a wise one as its inclusion would only detract from the volume as a reference work."Willis, Michael (2012). Review: Aśokan Sites and Artefacts. A Source-Book with Bibliography (Monographien zur Indischen Archäologie, Kunst und Philologie, Band 18) by Harry Falk, Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society, Third Series 22 (1), 187-188}} According to him, the inscription translates as "these are the relics of the Buddha, the Lord".[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HwhABtpl5Q8&feature=youtu.be&t=0m49s Excerpt from ''The Bones of the Buddha''] The conclusion is that the Piprahwa Stupa was built by the Emperor [[Ashoka]] 150 years later in 245 BCE over the original and simpler interment site created by Shakya clansmen for the 1/8th of the Buddha's ashes they had been apportioned. Falk points to the close similarity of materials used at Piprahwa and its grand size with other Ashokan stupas, and that the coffer containing the reliquary found at Piprahwa closely reflects Ashokan workmanship, design, and the type of [[sandstone]] used for monuments like the [[Lumbini]] pillar erected during his reign. (In 1971, Indian archeologist [[K.S. Srivastava]] excavated deeper into the stupa than Peppé had, uncovering two chambers each containing a soapstone casket with [[redware]] fragments. This is taken as confirmation of the existence of an earlier, deeper burial site at Piprahwa dating back to the death of the Buddha.) ==See also== * [[Popular history]] * [[Popularization of science]] * [[Relics associated with Buddha]] * [[Śarīra]] ==Notes== {{reflist|group=note|1}} ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:British films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:British television documentaries]] [[Category:2013 television films]] [[Category:Films set in India]] [[Category:Documentary films about science]] [[Category:History of India]] [[Category:History of Buddhism]]

[[File:Three Books of Occult Philosophy-Book III-Page 439.jpg|thumb|right|The Celestial Alphabet described in Agrippa's 'Of Occult Philosophy']] The '''Celestial Alphabet''', more commonly known as '''Angelic Script''', is an [[alphabet]] described by [[Heinrich Cornelius Agrippa]] in the 16th century. It is not to be confused with [[John Dee]] and [[Edward Kelley]]'s [[Enochian alphabet]], which is also sometimes called the Celestial alphabet. Other alphabets with a similar origin are [[Transitus Fluvii]] and [[Malachim]].
==External links== * [http://www.omniglot.com/writing/angelic.htm Description of the Celestial Alphabet]
{{Writingsystem-stub}} {{Occult-stub}}
